messageBody:
Try to stub the classes you are testing. You can stub almost anything. If it is not possible to stub classes wrap them. This can happen if you work with a class that is declared final. 
My one advice would be not to actually create a server connection for unit tests. Your tests are supposed to be simple. Try to create Fake server connection and pass them across.

Unit testing and refactoring should go hand in hand. If something is stopping you from unit testing, it would be a good time to start throwing away something. There is a problem here too. To ensure your refactoring is right you should have unit tests but then that is the purpose why you started refactoring. This is a chicken and egg problem. So start refactoring in small steps. 

There are some good articles in developerWorks featuring Unit testing. I have read the reviews of a book called "Working Effectively with Legacy Code"(http://www.amazon.com/Working-Effectively-Legacy-Robert-Martin/dp/0131177052/ref=pd_bxgy_b_img_a) which seems to be useful. I did not get my hands yet on this book.

I would suggest getting some hands on this book and something like this or taking a short training on agile training.

regards,
Suresh

From: Bradley, Todd <todd.bradley@...>
Subject: RE: [junit] unit testing clinet server applications?
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Date: Monday, June 29, 2009, 9:57 AM

















Is your application designed in such a way that you can test your code

without starting another process (for your server)? I've had better

luck mocking out server-side code at a slightly higher layer. In other

words, unless you don't trust the code that does your wire protocol and

TCP/IP communication, include that in the mock. Then your mock can just

be Java classes wired up at runtime, and you don't have to have the

headaches with starting and stopping another process.



Todd.
